metadata.title: High-fidelity probing of the structure and heterogeneity of extracellular vesicles by resonance-enhanced atomic force microscopy infrared spectroscopy

sections.text:
High-fidelity probing of the structure and heterogeneity of extracellular vesicles by resonance-enhanced atomic force microscopy infrared spectroscopy Sally Yunsun Kim 1,2, Dipesh Khanal1,2, Bill Kalionis3,4 and Wojciech Chrzanowski 1,2*
Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are highly specialized nanoscale assemblies that deliver complex biological cargos to mediate intercellular communication. EVs are heterogeneous, and characterization of this heterogeneity is paramount to understanding EV biogenesis and activity, as well as to associating them with biological responses and pathologies. Traditional approaches to studying EV composition generally lack the resolution and/or sensitivity to characterize individual EVs, and therefore the assessment of EV heterogeneity has remained challenging. We have recently developed an atomic force microscope IR spectroscopy (AFM-IR) approach to probe the structural composition of single EVs with nanoscale resolution. Here, we provide a step-by-step procedure for our approach and show its power to reveal heterogeneity across individual EVs, within the same population of EVs and between different EV populations. Our approach is label free and able to detect lipids, proteins and nucleic acids within individual EVs. After isolation of EVs from cell culture medium, the protocol involves incubation of the EV sample on a suitable substrate, setup of the AFM-IR instrument and collection of nano-IR spectra and nano-IR images. Data acquisition and analyses can be completed within 24 h, and require only a basic knowledge of spectroscopy and chemistry. We anticipate that new understanding of EV composition and structure through AFM-IR will contribute to our biological understanding of EV biology and could find application in disease diagnosis and the development of EV therapies.
Introduction
EVs are nano-sized biological messengers that carry heterogeneous molecular cargos (i.e., proteins, nucleic acids and lipids), which mediate cellular responses in recipient cells1. Depending on their cellular origin and biogenesis pathways, EVs have defined cell–cell communication roles in physiological and pathophysiological processes2,3. For better understanding and advancing the potential of EVs in clinical applications such as biomarkers of disease, drug delivery systems and therapeutics, it is critical to characterize EVs at the level of subpopulations and individual vesicles.
Despite the development of numerous advanced EV characterization methods in the past decade, deciphering the structure and composition of individual EVs remains an elusive challenge because of limitations in the sensitivity and resolution of conventional techniques. Conventional nanoscale techniques for the characterization of individual EVs are limited to obtaining information on particle morphology, size and number, rather than investigating their molecular compositions4. Furthermore, many of these techniques require fluorescent probes, which is a substantial limitation. Many of the desired probes do not exist, and some that are available not only provide restricted information but also have the potential to interfere with the biological function of the vesicles. Numerous phenotyping and molecular profiling methods, such as microarrays, RNA sequencing and mass spectrometry, are in use for identifying the composition of EVs5–8. However, their critical limitation is that they examine bulk EV samples instead of subpopulations or individual EVs1. Currently, large volumes of EVs are required and only the averaged signal from relatively large populations is obtained because of the insufficient resolution of conventional techniques. methods currently available to interrogate the heterogeneity of EVs restrict further progress in understanding EV biogenesis and function. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop new approaches to interrogate subpopulations and individual vesicles to enable further and rapid progress in EV sciences. A better understanding of EVs’ molecular composition and heterogeneity is fundamental to devising next-generation biosensors for early disease diagnosis and developing emerging EV-based therapies9,10, which already demonstrate great promise in cancer diagnosis and treatment.
Here, we present a detailed protocol for our recently developed approach using AFM-IR to interrogate the composition and structure of whole EV populations, subpopulations and individual EVs at the ultra-high resolution of ~20 nm (ref. 11). We have used this approach to demonstrate the capability to measure subtle differences between molecular compositions of individual EVs within the same EV population, or between different EV populations isolated from two types of placenta stem cell lines11. In the near future, AFM-IR characterization of EVs is highly likely to unlock the full potential of EVs as diagnostic and therapeutic tools11. We anticipate that AFM-IR-mediated characterization of EVs can be used as a tool for the early diagnosis of disease using liquid biopsies, as well as for selecting desired EV subpopulations for use in targeted therapy12,13. In particular, mesenchymal stromal cell–derived EVs are intensively studied for the regeneration of damaged or diseased tissues, and clinical administration of EVs, as opposed to whole cells, is believed to be safer and more practical14. Engineering of EVs for precision therapeutics15 and development of EVs as natural drug carriers through functionalization and internalization of therapeutics within the EV structures have been in the focus of recent EV research, especially in the cancer therapeutics field16,17. We expect that use of AFM-IR to resolve the heterogeneity of EVs and better understand the distinct molecular properties of subpopulations will unlock the full clinical potential of EVs18,19.

sections.heading: Development of the protocol
sections.text:
Despite the progress in the development of material characterization methods, many conventional methods have limited resolution and are suitable only for bulk materials. The first reports of using a conventional Fourier transform IR spectrometer (FTIR) coupled with a thermal source and a temperature-sensitive thermal probe were in 1999 and 2000, respectively, by Hammiche et al.20 and Anderson21. This method was, however, limited to single-point analysis. The currently used AFM-IR technique was first demonstrated by Dazzi et al.22. This pioneering work has found applications to characterize virtually any type of sample, including polymers, biofuels, nanomedicines, metal–organic frameworks, plasmonics, polymers and pharmaceuticals23,24. Further developments incorporating continuous oscillation of the cantilever to AFM-IR led to the development of resonance-enhanced AFM-IR, enabling increased sensitivity23,25. AFM-IR is extensively used for the nanoscale analysis of anisotropic materials, including large molecules and proteins26. AFM-IR has recently been used for determining conformational changes in intra- and extracellular protein structures that indicate altered biological function27, and for studying lipid droplets, vesicles and cytoskeletal filaments of cells at the subcellular level28.
However, the use of AFM-IR for characterizing complex biological nanostructures such as EVs has not been reported. The potential advantages of incorporating AFM-IR for the study of EVs were the ability to profile composition and structure of single EVs within a population, as well as for bulk comparison of EV populations. We anticipated that the abilities of AFM-IR for nanoscale structure and composition analysis of a single EV could be adapted to analyze heterogeneity within single EVs, and their populations and subpopulations. Most important, the protocol will enable qualitative and quantitative comparisons between individual EVs. This technique is a label-free method, which is a key advantage, for mapping IR-absorbing species of individual EVs, thereby enabling comparison of single EVs. With the outstanding resolution of <20 nm, AFM-IR can be used to probe multiple points on single EVs to interrogate differences in composition and structure within single EVs11. Such high resolution is attributed to the fast thermal expansion of the sample upon excitation with a focused pulse laser. This expansion induces the oscillations of the cantilever that remains in contact with the sample. The oscillation amplitude is proportional to the absorbed energy in the sample29. The oscillation in the sample is collected at different illumination wavelengths, Fourier-transformed and plotted as amplitude versus wavenumber. The frequency peaks observed in the spectra correspond to the vibration modes of the cantilever and reveal the chemistry of the nanoscale volume of the material below the cantilever contact point. Recorded IR spectra for EVs show characteristic peaks at specific wavenumbers, which are associated with chemical bonds and provide a molecular fingerprint. By analyzing the position and intensity of the peaks, it is possible to determine the presence of DNA

sections.heading: Overview of the procedure
sections.text:
To demonstrate the ability of AFM-IR to probe differences in molecular composition of vesicles from different cell types, we here use EVs isolated from two well-characterized telomerase reverse transcriptase (hTERT)-transformed human decidual (DMSC23) and chorionic (CMSC29) mesenchymal stromal cell lines30,31 (see the ‘Experimental design’ section for details). The workflow for performing AFM-IR measurements on isolated EVs is outlined in Fig. 1. EVs are extracted from serum-free conditioned medium (Steps 1–12). Because the production of EVs is stimulated as a result of the cell’s response to changes in the microenvironment32, cells can be cultured in various conditions, for example, in hypoxic conditions, which models the stressed environment of tissue injury.

Sample preparation for AFM-IR is done by placing a drop of EV sample (dispersed in nucleasefree water) on the substrate (e.g., zinc selenide (ZnSe) prism, mica and gold) and then drying it overnight (Steps 13–15). Upon initialization of nanoIR and collection of background IR spectra (Steps 16–21), the IR laser is aligned and optimized (Steps 22–44). Then AFM-IR spectra are acquired as the AFM tip detects and amplifies the thermal expansion signal (Steps 45–50). The AFM-IR spectra can be acquired from multiple EVs within a single population or from multiple points on single EVs in the 1,000–1,800 cm−1 range, and high-resolution spectra can be obtained at 1 cm−1 resolution. The AFM tip can map variations in thermal expansion from IR absorption at a slower scan rate of 0.1 Hz (Steps 51–57). These steps can then be repeated on several EVs in other regions of the prism, or other samples prepared on a different prism. Finally, the data are processed using the Analysis Studio software (Steps 58–60).

sections.heading: Applications of the method
sections.text:
Despite the different approaches available for measuring EV heterogeneity (see ‘Comparison with other methods’ below), determining the uniformity of their structure and composition, either in the whole EV population or in individual EVs, remains a challenge. AFM-IR is likely to be a vital tool for understanding EV structure and composition, and to correlate these properties with biological responses and function. AFM-IR can be used to provide basic, essential information on the structure and composition of EV populations, allowing databases of ‘fingerprint’ spectra to be created for EVs from any cell type. The ability to characterize individual EVs, and subpopulations of EVs, will help to increase our understanding of how cells communicate by determining how EV structure and composition change during key events in normal and pathological development.
The immediate practical application of AFM-IR is in testing and optimizing methods for the isolation of EVs that have the desired structure, size and/or composition. Furthermore, it is possible to determine the changes in EV structure and composition following changes to growth conditions, or following genetic manipulation of the source cell, which can change the composition of EVs.
The heterogeneity of EV populations produced by stem cells, and particularly by mesenchymal stromal cells, is a major problem that hinders their therapeutic use and effectiveness. Reproducibility and stringent analyses of the structure and composition of the EV population would assist in meeting regulatory requirements for clinical use. AFM-IR will allow a fast and reliable means of determining the ideal conditioning method to produce the best-quality therapeutic EVs, with minimal amounts of samples required for screening.
Recent studies point to EVs as early markers for the diagnosis and progression of various diseases, including cancer19,33,34. Alterations in EV numbers, surface proteins and nucleic acid molecular cargos are used as markers of disease prognosis10,18. AFM-IR can potentially be used to correlate changes of EV ‘fingerprints’ of molecular compositions with diseases, which could facilitate early disease detection. This highly sensitive method has the potential to improve the accuracy of diagnostic and disease prognostic tools. When clinically validated, AFM-IR would support the development of personalized therapies based on EV spectra disease phenotypes, which would benefit individual and overall health outcomes. The AFM-IR could be further developed to become the foundation for future biosensors for disease detection. Our new method to characterize EVs using nanoscale AFM-IR may unlock the potential of EVs, allowing them to be utilized as clinical tools in both diagnosis and therapy.
Finally, EVs are extensively studied for their potential as natural drug carriers to deliver diverse types of therapeutic drugs. We anticipate that AFM-IR can be used to assess EV structural and compositional changes that follow encapsulation of drug molecules. Such information is likely to enhance our understanding of the relationship between EV structure/composition and therapeutic efficacy.
Comparison with other methods There are several alternative label-free approaches available that can be used to obtain information on the structure and molecular composition of EVs. Although IR spectroscopy is a discriminative method for label-free extraction of biochemical information from biological samples35, there are limitations to the resolution of currently used methods for the characterization of EVs. FTIR is one of the most commonly used IR methods for biological samples35–37. However, the main limitation of FTIR is its spatial resolution, which ranges between 3 and 30 µm, depending on the instrumentation used. Thus, the use of FTIR provides microscale, averaged and bulk signal from a large sample population (micrograms) and is unsuitable for single-EV characterization38.

Raman spectroscopy is also used to characterize biochemical and structural information for biological samples39. As with FTIR, Raman spectroscopy is suitable only for measuring relatively large sample volumes, lacks sensitivity for individual EVs and provides readout from bulk EV preparations. More recently, enhanced Raman spectroscopy techniques such as Raman tweezers microspectroscopy (RTM) and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) have emerged and offer higher sensitivity for biological samples than standard Raman spectroscopy40. However, until now, there has been no report that demonstrates sufficient sensitivity to probe individual vesicles. Despite improved sensitivity, both RTM and SERS remain techniques that are predominantly suitable for characterization of larger EV populations41,42.
Robust characterization of the elaborate structure of individual EVs is very dependent on ultra-high (nanoscale) resolution. In general, IR spectroscopy achieves higher resolution because it measures the light absorbance, which is more specific than measuring light scattering, as is done in Raman spectroscopy. Ultra-high resolution can be obtained by combining IR with resonance-enhanced atomic force microscopy—AFM-IR. AFM-IR is capable of simultaneously mapping morphological features on the EV surface in 3D, determining physical properties as well as chemical composition, at the nanoscale. A major advantage of this method, not offered by the other techniques, is the connection of all signals by correlative nanospectroscopy. The volume of sample required for AFM-IR is in the range of a few microliters (5-µl volume containing ~80 µg of EVs), which is substantially lower than the amount required for Raman-based and conventional FTIR methods.
A method for the analysis of EV composition by attenuated total reflection FTIR (ATR-FTIR) was recently patented for the application of "diagnosing, prognosing and monitoring pathophysiological states for biological samples"43. Although the ATR mode allows for higher sensitivity, resolution remains in the microscale, whereas AFM-IR enables characterization at ultra-high, nanoscale resolution (<20 nm). AFM-IR is a powerful tool for evaluating the nanoscale composition of individual EVs and can be used to identify physical structures of EVs that have previously been exceptionally difficult to correlatively detect and analyze. With the capabilities of AFM-IR, we are able to obtain detailed information on EV chemical composition and physical properties at nanoscale.

sections.heading: Limitations
sections.text:
Although there are many advantages of using AFM-IR for EV characterization, there are also some important limitations to consider. First, smaller vesicles (20–50 nm) may not provide a strong enough IR signal for reliable characterization of individual vesicles. Therefore, for smaller vesicles, when the IR signal is too weak, a more concentrated sample may be required, which will result in a signal increase. However, in more concentrated samples, EVs typically aggregate, and thus the acquired spectra will represent the averaged chemical composition of small aggregates of EVs (typically several EVs). Regardless of the sample concentration, when comparing EV composition between multiple EVs within a subpopulation, there is a need to scan several areas and acquire spectra from different locations across the sample to enable robust statistical analysis.
AFM-IR imaging requires the optimization of the data collection conditions (as described in the ‘Experimental design’ section), as well as uniformity of the samples. Owing to possible nonlinearities in energy absorption across samples of different thickness or of heterogeneous composition, AFM-IR images are often referred as semiquantitative44. In the protocol presented here, we followed the requirements to eliminate nonlinearities to produce reliable and quantitative data. However, it must be understood that biological samples, such as vesicles, cannot be homogeneous because they are ‘randomly’ packaged by cells; thus, a small amount of nonlinearity can be expected and needs to be compensated for by collection of a large number of spectra.
When using AFM-IR, caution should be taken when interpreting the results for samples that present clear orientation. For oriented samples, polarization of the incident light will influence IR peak intensities, depending on the rotation of the bond with respect to the light. Because AFM-IR systems use polarized light, crystallinity and orientation in the sample influence relative IR peak intensities. Consequently, if we can control specific orientation in the material, the polarization of the light source will have an effect on the relative band ratios, and if the orientation varies across the sample surface, local variation in IR images will be presented. However, if the sample is not oriented, as is the case for EVs and many other biological samples, then the specific polarization can be ignored. Polarization is likely to be a concern in the following situations:

sections.heading: Experimental design
sections.text: We present a detailed procedure for the isolation of EVs and their characterization by AFM-IR spectroscopy. Although the bottom-up illumination and the use of the optical parametric oscillator (OPO) laser source offer important advantages for biological samples, we standardized the procedure for obtaining quantitative and reproducible data regardless of the type of the AFM-IR being used.

sections.heading: Selection of cells and isolation of EVs
sections.text:
We here demonstrate our protocol using EVs secreted by mesenchymal stromal cells, which have been extensively researched for their applications in regenerative medicine. We isolate EVs from two well-characterized hTERT-transformed human decidual (DMSC23) and chorionic (CMSC29) mesenchymal stromal cell lines30,31. DMSC23 and CMSC29 are used because they retain many of the important characteristics of mesenchymal stromal/stem cells30,31. Moreover, the use of these cell lines ensures reproducibility by avoiding the confounder of patient-to-patient variation between primary mesenchymal stromal cell preparations.
The DMSC23 cell line is of particular interest because the mesenchymal stromal cells used to generate this cell line were isolated from the maternal (decidua basalis) component of the placenta. These cells are naturally resistant to elevated levels of oxidative stress, which are a characteristic of pregnancy30,31. DMSCs, which are conditioned to resist oxidative stress, are expected to have a specialized biological cargo packaged in their EVs. CMSC29 cells are chosen for comparison of structure and composition because they are derived mesenchymal stromal cells from the fetal chorionic component of the placenta, which are not as resistant to oxidative stress as DMSC23 cells31. We therefore expect the two cell lines to produce EVs that are different in their structure and composition. Conditioned medium is first centrifuged to remove cellular debris and apoptotic bodies, and this is followed by ultracentrifugation to isolate the EVs. Ultracentrifugation remains the method of choice to isolate EVs (Steps 5–12). To avoid interference from PBS crystals in the AFM-IR measurement (Supplementary Fig. 1a), the EV pellet resulting from the ultracentrifugation step is dispersed in nuclease-free water before drying on the substrate (Steps 13–15). In addition, the sample must be properly immobilized, to avoid dragging during imaging (Supplementary Fig. 1b).

sections.heading: Type of AFM-IR instruments
sections.text:
Currently used AFM-IR systems include the OPO-based first-generation AFM-IR and the quantum cascade laser (QCL)-based AFM-IR. The OPO covers a broader range of the mid-IR spectrum, using two stages of measurement, whereas the QCL source has a line width of <1 cm−1 over the full range. The sample illumination depending on the instrument configuration can be bottom up or top down, each of which has some limitations and advantages.
This protocol was originally developed using a bottom-up illumination of the sample by a pulsed, tunable IR OPO laser source, AFM-IR (nanoIR). However, the protocol presented here can be used for the characterization of EVs using any AFM-IR instrument.
The fundamental benefit of the bottom-up nanoIR configuration is that there is little illumination of the AFM probe in this geometry. Because of the total internal reflection that occurs at the prism surface, most of the light is reflected and only the evanescent field illuminates the sample. This provides a very low ‘background’ signal. In the top-down configurations, the probe is illuminated by the IR light, which can result in a signal even if the sample has no absorption. Although the use of QCL-based systems allows for fast spectra acquisition in general, the quality of data for vesicles is of paramount importance; thus, bottom-up illumination has proven highly beneficial.

Furthermore, the ability to collect simultaneous topography, IR absorbance and cantilever peak frequency—stiffness images—is an important benefit for biological samples in the OPO-based AFMIR. Some of the newer generation of QCL-based AFM-IR systems have limited capability of doing this in a straightforward fashion. Because mechanobiological data correlate with structure and biological function45, this set of data provides a substantial level of confidence and additional validation of the results.
One of the perceived limitations of the first generation of AFM-IR systems is the requirement for the use of a ZnSe prism. At times, the handling of the prism can be inconvenient because it needs to be done with care. Therefore, Step 14 in this protocol is specific to the sample substrate used in the original Anasys Instruments nanoIR model, that is, ZnSe prisms.
Level of expertise needed to implement the protocol The operation of AFM-IR requires training, but the general operation of the nanoIR equipment is not overly difficult and does not necessarily require prior experience in AFM and/or IR spectroscopy. Some knowledge of how the AFM-IR works is preferred. Care must be taken in the systems when a prism is required for the measurements to ensure that it is correctly placed into the prism holder.
Sample preparation and the isolation of EVs from cell lines requires cell culture and tissue culture training, and care should be taken to minimize nuclease contamination. The interpretation of IR spectra requires basic knowledge of spectroscopy and chemistry to analyze the results correctly.
Acquiring AFM-IR spectra from individual EVs Proper laser alignment and optimization (Steps 22–44; Fig. 2) before AFM-IR spectra acquisition are critical for obtaining accurate spectra. When the IR signal is collected without focusing the IR laser on the cantilever, a number of peaks may be attenuated or not present, which produces inaccurate data, as those peaks may not be precisely detectable and interpretable (Supplementary Fig. 1c).
The properly aligned AFM-IR laser produces spectra such as those presented in the ‘Anticipated results’ section. After obtaining the AFM height image (topography), cursors are placed to indicate regions for AFM-IR measurement. To identify differences in composition and structure of individual EVs within the same population, several vesicles are selected, and spectra are acquired individually for each vesicle (Fig. 3). In comparisons of two EV populations, vesicles with similar height and size are selected to be analyzed, and cursors are placed on the middle of the vesicle to minimize inconsistency.

Collection of nano-IR image (high-resolution mapping) The nano-IR image (Fig. 4) is an ultra-high-resolution map of chemistry at a given wavenumber that provides a quantitative image of the chemical heterogeneity within a single vesicle. For nano-IR imaging, the scan rate is reduced so that the update of IR peak, IR amplitude and frequency data approximates the pixel rate of the image (Steps 51–57). For example, at a scan rate of 0.1 Hz, it takes 10 s to scan both trace and retrace lines. With an ‘X’ resolution of 500 in each scan direction, this correlates to a pixel rate of 100 Hz. The repetition rate of the IR source is 1 kHz, and with the coaverages of 16×, the update rate of the IR peak, amplitude and frequency would be ~60 Hz, which is similar to the pixel rate. If the co-average value is increased, the scan rate must be decreased to match the pixel rate and to update all the necessary signals for image acquisition. The mismatch of scan rate and co-average will result in failure of image acquisition.
The nano-IR image can be collected at various wavenumbers of interest so that the ratio of images can be compared to localize various chemical domains within the sample on the basis of color intensity (Fig. 4). For example, if an amide I peak of protein is seen at 1,640 cm−1 and a lipid-related cholesterol peak is seen at 1,730 cm−1, two separate IR images can be collected at these wavenumbers in order to identify the distribution of lipid and protein across the sample being scanned (Fig. 4). High-resolution mapping enabled us to identify and localize specific compounds within vesicles and to establish critical differences between CMSCs and DMSCs11. By scanning several vesicles, we provided further evidence of heterogeneity in vesicle composition11.
Data analysis using the Analysis Studio processing software When spectra are collected either from multiple EVs, or as an array from single EVs, dedicated software can be used to process spectra for averaging or smoothing (Analysis Studio, Steps 58–60). Smoothing of the spectra can be achieved using a ‘Savitzky–Golay’ function. The choice of polynomial function, and the number of points selected, is critical. The higher the number of points used for smoothing, the greater the risk of losing critical peaks of lower intensity during the smoothing process. From our experience and optimization, ideal smoothing can be achieved by using a polynomial function of 2, and 15 number points. When labeling the peaks, the appropriate minimum amplitude value must be specified to minimize the labeling of noise. A minimum amplitude of 5 will result in labeling of peaks associated with noise, and therefore higher values should be chosen. The individual peaks in the spectra can be labeled either automatically using a function in the software, or manually by moving the highlighting bar on top of the peak of interest.

sections.heading: Controls
sections.text:
It is essential to include samples of the nuclease-free water used to disperse EVs after ultracentrifugation and the medium for EV isolation without exposure to cells. This is to ensure that there are no contaminants in the nuclease-free water used and that there is minimal protein contamination in the medium used for EV isolation.

Procedure
Cell culture and change to serum-free medium ● Timing ~3 d 1 Culture DMSC23 or CMSC29 cells until 80% confluence in normal culture medium. We
recommend using three T75 flasks as a minimum culture size to obtain a sufficient amount of EV samples for three replicates for AFM-IR; each flask provides an adequate amount of EVs for one sample preparation. However, when conducting other analyses for the same batch of EV sample, such as transmission electron microscopy, nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA) or nanoflow analysis (nanoflow cytometry (nanoFCM)), culturing and obtaining samples from an additional five to ten T75 flasks or three to six T175 flasks are necessary. The number of plates depends on the extent of the other analyses. As a control sample, either commercially available EVs (lyophilized and purified exosomes from cell culture medium HansaBioMed Life Science, Lonza) or a purified protein sample (e.g., fibronectin) can be recommended.
c CRITICAL STEP For the purpose of our study, cells were grown either in normal conditions (37 °C, 5% CO2) or under hypoxic conditions. We cultured cells in 1% O2, 5% CO2 and 94% N2 inside a hypoxia chamber. Hypoxia was chosen to mimic physiological stress observed during pregnancy (low partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of human placenta), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and asthma. Furthermore, our research aims to address a fundamental question about how oxidative stress impacts the production and composition of EVs. Note: the selection of the conditions should be done on the basis of your biological/research question. 2 Wash the cells twice with 10 ml of HBSS(−). 3 Remove the normal culture medium and replace it with serum-free EV isolation medium (12 ml per
T75 flask or 23 ml per T175 flask; see 'Reagent setup'). 4 After 48 h, collect the medium and transfer it to nuclease-free centrifuge tubes.

the ZnSe prism for bottom-up illumination or onto a substrate for top-down illumination. ! CAUTION Zinc selenide is a skin and eye irritant, and is toxic if inhaled or ingested. Always wear gloves when handling prisms, and wear a face mask to prevent inhalation or ingestion of any dust residue. Read the material safety data sheet (MSDS) available from the supplier.

Large differences between the charge of the EVs and that of the ZnSe prism favor robust, electrostatic attachment of EVs. CAUTION Avoid staring directly into the laser beam, as it is hazardous to the eyes. 19 Before placing the sample substrate, collect IR background spectra in the same range as that in which the data will be collected, for example, 1,000–1,800 cm−1. It is recommended to collect IR background spectra a minimum of 30 min after the laser was switched on, which allows stabilization of its temperature and power. ? For unexperienced AFM users, a fast, manual approach may result in uncontrolled contact of the tip with the surface, causing damage to the tip. We recommend approaching the substrate with a speed between 2 and 10 µm/min until the cantilever edges become visible, but blurred, on the microscope screen while the sample is in focus. 27 Scan the surface to obtain AFM images in ‘Contact Mode’.
c CRITICAL STEP While collecting the topographical height images, adjust the speed of the scan to ~0.3–0.7 Hz, and set point, integral and proportional gain so that the trace and retrace graphs of the cantilever lines are overlapping. EVs are soft samples, and these adjustments will prevent vesicle dragging or damage during the scan. 28 Move the cantilever tip to the vesicle of interest. Keep the cantilever in contact with the vesicle. c CRITICAL STEP Keep the probe engaged on the sample, but do not scan for image acquisition. 29 Turn on the green aiming laser and align it onto the end of the cantilever.
c CRITICAL STEP Move the green aiming laser to the right and left ends of the prism to ensure the proper alignment of the prism with the prism holder. Ensure that the prism is clean: a focused spot of the green laser indicates that the prism is clean, whereas a more dispersed laser indicates that the prism is not clean. 30 After the alignment of laser, turn off the aiming laser by clicking on the ‘Stop Guide Laser’ button of the software. 31 Enter the wavenumber into the software where the sample is highly likely to have an absorbance. For example, if the sample contains proteins, enter a wavenumber of 1,640 cm−1 for optimization of the IR signal. 32 Switch on the IR by clicking on the ‘Start IR’ software button. 33 Adjust the IR focus by adjusting the IR focus wheel to align the IR laser with the cantilever;
manually rotate the focus wheel for first-generation AFM-IR or where the motorized focus is unavailable; otherwise use motorized controllers in the software to adjust the focus position. Pay attention to the deflection and fast Fourier transform (FFT) plots to obtain a cantilever ringdown signal in a wave form and a clear peak in the FFT plot (Fig. 2a,b). 34 Disable the band-pass filter to observe the ringdown signal and to observe the peaks in the FFT window. 35 Look for a clear peak in the FFT window; choose the second cantilever resonance peak, which is typically >75 kHz, as a frequency center; and enter 50 kHz as into the software as the frequency window. 36 Set the power of the laser to obtain a maximum ringdown deflection amplitude of ~0.1 arbitrary units (a.u.). Ideally, pre-optimize the ringdown with gain set to 0 by adjusting the focus of the laser; rotate the IR focus wheel to obtain a cantilever deflection reading in the IR meter within ±0.1 or higher. If the signal is very weak (<0.02), it is recommended to set the gain to 25–50% and to continue pre-optimizing the laser position. Once the position is pre-optimized, set the gain back to 0. For vesicles, the laser power may need to be as high as 80–90% to obtain sufficient strength of the signal. Set co-averages to 256×.

Typically, the wavenumber chosen for biological samples such as EVs are 1,050, 1,150, 1,250, 1,350, 1,450, 1,550, 1,650 and 1,750 cm−1, for a scan range of 1,000–1,800 cm−1 (Fig. 2c).

If the laser position is changed, the entire process of laser optimization and alignment must be repeated. 45 Enter the range of wavenumbers within which the spectral acquisition is to be done—for example, from 1,000 to 1,800 cm−1. 46 Enter the resolution of spectra to be acquired—typically 1 cm−1 for high-resolution spectra. 47 Enter the co-averages as 256× or higher. The higher the value of co-averages, the better the signal-

done and click on ‘Acquire’ in the software to collect the spectra. For automated acquisition, click on the ‘Array’ button in the software, which will open the previously acquired image of the vesicle. Multiple EVs or multiple points on a single EV can be selected to acquire spectra. To collect spectra from multiple EVs, identify EVs of interest on the height image. Select EVs for which spectra should be collected by placing the cursor and clicking ‘pick a point’ on each of the EVs and then acquire the spectra. When analyzing multiple points within a single EV, scan the selected EVs using a smaller scan size to have one or two EVs in the image; typically, 500 × 500 nm is sufficient. 49 When prompted, select the ‘Line array’ or ‘Grid array’ option to collect the spectra from different spatial locations within the image. For example, with a 1 × 1-µm scan size, ‘Grid array’ can be chosen with 10–12 spots on the image for collecting spectra across the sample. Higher numbers of points increase the resolution of the data. 50 Monitor the spectra, as well as the IR deflection window for the level of IR absorbance signal being collected, as the spectra are collected. If the IR power is greater than ±1 during the spectral acquisition, stop the scan and reduce the IR laser power to avoid sample damage. Strong shift in the resonance frequency at absorption peaks is an indicator of sample damage. Furthermore, we recommend taking topographic images after spectra to ensure that no sample damage is observed.
c CRITICAL STEP Minimal time between the collection of background and spectral acquisition of sample is highly recommended to reduce the risk of a system drift. If necessary (critical in the case of top-down and (QCL-based nanoIR instruments), collect a new background after optimizing the laser focus immediately before collecting real data on a sample. This will also ensure that the water vapor in the laser beam path is better compensated for. It is highly recommended that the instrument be housed in a temperature- and humidity-controlled environment, to reduce the influence of the temperature and water vapor on collected data.

Anticipated results
We demonstrated the ability to identify differences in the composition and structure of individual EVs within the same EV population at nanoscale by using DMSC23 and CMSC29 EVs. Figure 3a shows a collection of AFM-IR spectra from individual EVs in a population of DMSC23 EVs, which were collected from DMSC23 cells cultured under hypoxia. Figure 3b shows the corresponding AFM height image, in which blue and red grids indicate the areas where spectra were collected. The spectra in blue, collected from two points of the same large vesicle, show two distinct peaks of increased intensity at 1,725 cm−1 (fatty acids) and 1,240 cm−1 (phosphates), which are consistent with increased amounts of lipids and nucleic acids on the surface and inside the vesicle, respectively. The peak corresponding to RNA ribose at 1,124 cm−1 shows differences in the intensities for each spectrum, which indicates the different amounts of RNA ribose contained in these EVs. These data

demonstrate that AFM-IR is a method that is sensitive enough to uncover nanoscale differences in molecular composition between individual EVs, and the data highlight the heterogeneity of EV populations.
The AFM-IR spectra obtained for these EV samples also show differences in the amide I peaks. Changes to the amide I peak can also be attributed to different concentrations and types of nucleic acids, which have peaks between 1,800 cm−1 and 1,500 cm−1 (Fig. 4). To discriminate between changes to the protein conformation and the contribution from nucleic acid, the calculation of a second derivative from the spectra is required. This analysis separates individual peaks associated with different components of nucleic acid and presents distinct differences in the composition and structure at the nanoscale level.
The ultra-high resolution of AFM-IR is demonstrated by its ability to probe multiple points within an individual EV, as well as its ability to identify differences between single EVs, either within the same or within different EV populations11. An example of this is shown in the averaged AFM-IR spectra of 12 points on a single DMSC23 EV, and those of a single CMSC29 EV (Fig. 5). The stronger intensities of the peaks at 1,556 cm−1 and 1,452 cm−1 for the DMSC23 EV belong to amide I and the bending vibration of lipid acyl CH2 groups, respectively, whereas the stronger intensities of peaks at 1,124 cm
−1, 1,087 cm−1 and 1,044 cm−1 for the CMSC29 EV are in the region of stretching vibration of phospholipids, triglycerides and cholesterol esters (950–1,200 cm−1), corresponding to the lipid content of the EV46. The peak at 1,124 cm−1, in particular, belongs to the RNA ribose, as mentioned above.

metadata.abstractText: Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are highly specialized nanoscale assemblies that deliver complex biological cargos to mediate intercellular communication. EVs are heterogeneous, and characterization of this heterogeneity is paramount to understanding EV biogenesis and activity, as well as to associating them with biological responses and pathologies. Traditional approaches to studying EV composition generally lack the resolution and/or sensitivity to characterize individual EVs, and therefore the assessment of EV heterogeneity has remained challenging. We have recently developed an atomic force microscope IR spectroscopy (AFM-IR) approach to probe the structural composition of single EVs with nanoscale resolution. Here, we provide a step-by-step procedure for our approach and show its power to reveal heterogeneity across individual EVs, within the same population of EVs and between different EV populations. Our approach is label free and able to detect lipids, proteins and nucleic acids within individual EVs. After isolation of EVs from cell culture medium, the protocol involves incubation of the EV sample on a suitable substrate, setup of the AFM-IR instrument and collection of nano-IR spectra and nano-IR images. Data acquisition and analyses can be completed within 24 h, and require only a basic knowledge of spectroscopy and chemistry. We anticipate that new understanding of EV composition and structure through AFM-IR will contribute to our biological understanding of EV biology and could find application in disease diagnosis and the development of EV therapies.
